questions.text: 1. A 12 year old boy presents with pain and swelling in the left leg. On examination, the leg is swollen and warm. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and CRP levels. An X-ray shows sclerotic bone fragments with surrounding lucencies in the medulla. Which of the following is unlikely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of pain, swelling, elevated ESR/CRP, and sclerotic bone with lucencies on X-ray suggests chronic osteomyelitis. Among the organisms listed, Klebsiella is least likely to cause this.

The causative organisms of chronic osteomyelitis are:

* Staphylococcus aureus

* Escherichia coli (Option D)

* Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B)

* Proteus mirabilis

* Pseudomonas aeruginosa

* Staphylococcus epidermidis in the presence of foreign implants

* Mycobacterium tuberculosis, especially in endemic regions, can cause tuberculous osteomyelitis (Option C) 

In contrast, Klebsiella species are rarely associated with osteomyelitis. While Klebsiella can cause a range of infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections, its involvement in bone infections is uncommon. 

In chronic osteomyelitis, the patient presents with pain, pyrexia, redness and tenderness or with a discharging sinus. In long-standing cases, the tissues are thickened and often puckered or folded inwards where a scar or sinus adheres to the underlying bone. There may be a seropurulent discharge and excoriation of the surrounding skin. During acute flares, ESR, CRP and WBC count may be increased.

questions.text: 2. A 17 year old boy presents with leg pain and difficulty walking. His X-ray shows sunburst pattern and periosteal elevation (Codman’s triangle). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with X-Ray showing sunburst appearance and periosteal elevantion (Codman's triangle) is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. It has a bimodal age distribution peak in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.

 It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal femur and humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle (image below) or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.



Other options:

Option A: Giant cell tumor:

It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour, commonly affecting the age group of 20-45 years. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings (image below): 

* Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis

* Soap bubble appearance

* Periosteal new bone formation is absent



Option B: Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 10-20 years and more frequently in males. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings (image below): Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.



Option D: Chondrosarcoma: It is the second most common primary malignant tumors that occurs in any site of the bone. It presents in 3rd to 8th decade of life and is slow growing, with deep pain and/or shows an enlarging mass. Most commonly involves proximal femur, pelvis and proximal humerus.

Radiographic findings (image below): Large, intraosseous and osteolytic tumors. Irregular and granular calcifications present which shows a characteristic “honeycomb” or “popcorn”appearance.

questions.text: 3. What is the WHO recommended investigation of choice for spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
CBNAAT Is the WHO recommended investigation of choice for spinal tuberculosis.

WHO recommends CBNAAT (GeneXpert) as the investigation of choice for diagnosis of extra-pulmonary tuberculosis, especially for CSF, lymph nodes and other tissue specimens. It has the lowest turnaround time (2 hours) among all the diagnostic methods. It is based on real-time PCR technique and simultaneously detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex DNA and rifampicin resistance (mutations of the rpoB gene). It uses five probes targeting various sequences of rpoB gene. 

In cases of extrapulmonary TB, the demonstration of acid-fast bacilli on the smear is difficult because the bacillary load itself is low. For this reason, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for extrapulmonary TB. Traditional methods such as culture and sensitivity take a long time of around 4-6 weeks. Hence, there is a need for a rapid diagnostic test like CBNAAT (Option B).

Spinal tuberculosis (Pott's spine) is always secondary. The bacteria reach the spine via the haematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes. It spreads via the para-vertebral plexus of veins i.e., Batson's plexus, which has free communication with the visceral plexus of the abdomen, a common site of tuberculosis. Clinical features include pain, stuffiness, swelling (cold abscess), paraplegia or deformity (gibbus). 

The spine is the commonest site of bone and joint tuberculosis. It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. MRI is the radiological investigation of choice. Imaging studies like X-rays or NCCT scans may indicate bony destruction or evidence of abscess but they are not the investigation of choice.  (Option C and D).

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The image below shows the various patterns of involvement in Pott's spine:



Pearl PM1720: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases.  All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months HRZE 4 months HRE (Only HR as per WHO guidelines)


Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

* Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

* Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 

* Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

* Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.

* Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: 4. A 35 year old laborer after falling on his outstreched hand presents with pain and swelling over the anatomical snuff box. X Ray is unremarkable. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Thumb spica cast and review after 10-14 days for imaging
MRI to rule out ligamental injuries

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, history of a fall on an outstretched hand followed by pain and swelling over the anatomical snuffbox, despite normal X-ray findings, is suggestive of scaphoid fracture. The next step in the management is to apply a thumb spica cast and review after 10-14 days for imaging.

All the cases of scaphoid fracture with high clinical suspicion with the absence of fracture line on X-ray should be treated with a scaphoid cast for 2 weeks. After 2 weeks repeat imaging is done because up to 30% of patients may have positive follow-up radiographs. Sometimes, the fracture becomes visible at this stage, because of resorption of the fracture ends. If no fracture is seen even at 2 weeks, no further treatment is required. 

A scaphoid fracture is more common in young adults. Commonly, the fracture occurs through the waist of the scaphoid. Clinical features include pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, one may be able to elicit tenderness in the scaphoid fossa(anatomical snuff box). X-ray with an oblique view of the wrist is taken in addition to the anteroposterior and lateral views. Sometimes a fracture line is not visible on initial X-rays. If a fracture is strongly suspected, X-rays should be repeated after 2 weeks.



The affected hand is immobilized in a scaphoid cast for 3-4 months. The scaphoid cast extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads including the thumb up to the inter-phalangeal joint. The wrist is maintained in a little dorsiflexion and radial deviation (glass holding position). In widely displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation using a special compression screw (Herbert's screw) is required.

The common complications of scaphoid fracture include:

* Non-union and delayed union

* Avascular necrosis

* Wrist osteoarthritis

Other options:

Options B and C: If pain persists but repeat X-rays remain normal, MRI or CT can then be considered. MRI is more sensitive than CT and has a negative predictive value of 100%, but it is expensive and not always readily available. In contrast, initial immobilization with re-evaluation is a safe and cost-effective approach. Urgent CT or MRI should only be considered if an acute diagnosis is absolutely necessary.

It's important to note that even if an urgent CT confirms a fracture, the patient would still be treated conservatively with thumb spica immobilization. Conversely, if the CT is negative but clinical suspicion remains high, immobilization would still continue with repeat imaging planned later. In other words, CT does not change the initial management, making it an unnecessary early investigation. Furthermore, the primary concern here is a possible scaphoid fracture—not a ligamentous injury. Even if MRI were to reveal a ligamentous injury, the immediate management would still involve immobilization in a thumb spica cast.

Option D: Discharging the patient with only analgesia is inappropriate because a clinically suspected scaphoid fracture, even with a normal initial X-ray, carries a significant risk of complications such as non-union or avascular necrosis due to the bone’s tenuous blood supply. Without proper immobilization, even a small, undetected fracture can worsen, leading to chronic complications.

questions.text: 5. A 75 year old lady presents with intertrochanteric fracture. What is the management of choice?
questions.solution:
The management of choice for a 75 year old lady presenting with intertrochanteric fracture is proximal femoral Intramedullary nailing.

The intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by intramedullary and extramedullary implants.

* Intramedullary implants include proximal femoral nail and gamma nail which are used in displaced/unstable intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. Compared to dynamic hip screws, the intramedullary fixation with proximal femoral nails has smaller incisions, decreased blood loss, decreased femoral neck shortening, and decreased risk of infection.

* Extramedullary implants include a dynamic hip screw which is used in undisplaced/stable inter-trochanteric fractures

The below image shows the proximal femoral nail with locking and stabilization screws.



Below image shows the dynamic hip screw. It has a long cancellous screw which glides freely inside the sleeve of the side plate.



Inter-trochanteric fracture

Fractures in the inter-trochanteric region of the proximal femur, involving either the greater or the lesser trochanter or both, are grouped in this category. In the elderly, the fracture is normally sustained by a sideway fall or a blow over the greater trochanter. In the young, it occurs following violent trauma, as in a road traffic accident.

Clinical features include a history of a fall or road accident, followed by pain in the region of the groin and an inability to move the leg. There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be short and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter.

X-ray of an inter-trochanteric fracture



Complications include malunion and osteoarthritis.

Other options:

Option B and C: Internal fixation with screws and hemiarthroplasty  are used mainly for neck of femur fractures, as shown below:



Option D: Boot and Bar traction can be used for conservative management, especially for moribund patients but it is not the management of choice
